lag.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to move or develop more slowly than others
lag.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: She stopped to wait for Ian who was lagging behind.
Britain is lagging behind the rest of Europe.
lag.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to cover water pipes etc with a special material to prevent the water inside them from freezing or the heat from being lost
lag.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: We’ve had the hot-water tank lagged.
lag.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: a delay or period of waiting between one event and a second event
lag.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to move, develop, or improve more slowly than others
lag.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: The sales team are lagging in their progress towards this quarter’s performance goals.
US firms lag behind nations such as Germany in training their staff.
lag.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: to change in amount or level at a later time than something else
lag.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: Even after the economy begins growing, hiring new employees tends to lag.
The increase in wages lagged behind the increase in prices through much of the decade.
lag.translation[2].definitions[2].defini: if prices of shares, traded goods, etc lag, they do not increase
lag.translation[2].definitions[2].exampl: While silver has lagged, it hasn’t been as weak as platinum.
lag.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: a delay in a change or improvement in something
lag.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: More problematic over the long term is a lag in attitudes. The country was the least reform-minded in Eastern Europe.
lag.translation[3].definitions[1].defini: a period of time that passes before an amount or level changes
lag.translation[3].definitions[1].exampl: There’s usually a lag between an upturn in manufacturing activity and increased shipments of factory machinery.
When taxes drop, the Massachusetts economy typically responds after a short lag, which used to be three years and now is half that.
